messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - do you have any set of test cases for non-conformant HTML5?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:12): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: there are some in the syntax module
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:12): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I've also used Anne's WF 2.0 tests, but using those in the test harness in now broken
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:13): as the spec stabilizes it makes sense to write more tests
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - btw, do you have a good estimate of many man hours you have put into work on the conformance checker?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:19): ... including hours of any others that contributed to it significantly (fantasai, maybe?)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:20): I'm just curious
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:25): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: no estimate. lots
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the upper bound I can give is that there's no code written by me in there that predates October 2003.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:28): And the validation service started around November 2004, IIRC.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:28): Work towards applying it to HTML began in the summer of 2005.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:30): The November 2004 date is my guess about starting design and implementation. it wasn't public until 2005

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - OK. Was just thinking mainly about the HTML5 part, and thinking it might be good to eventually try to have an rough estimate of how many man hours are needed to implement a complete HTML5 conformance checker.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:33): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I cannot give an estimate that would be even remotely accurate. But I can say that the parser isn't the biggest part, so the reasoning "we have a parser in language foo, let's make a conformance checker" is missing the point

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:35): One thing I wonder is, given all the dependencies of your Java implementation, how much extra work it will be to try to implement a checker in another language.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:35): other languages
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:36): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the biggest question is if you another programming language plus the same schemas or a totally independent impl
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:36): which I guess maybe are likely to lack equivalent libraries to depend on
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:37): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: but it is going to be a lot of work. I'm far from considering the Java impl complete

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - yeah, I know. about the schemas, seems like it would probably not be the most productive approach to try to implement something in another language that didn't also rely partly on schema validation
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:57): http://www.elementary-group-standards.com/html/html5-doctype-is-unrecognized.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:57): Sean Fraser
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:58): "Sean Fraser posted this on January 22, 2007 08:30 AM."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:58): I reckon I should probably add his feed to the nascent HTML5 blog aggregator
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:59): he does post a lot about it
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:59): seems only fair
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:59): s/only fair/correct/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:02): OK, added him
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:02): http://people.w3.org/mike/planet/html5/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:03): any others anybody's aware of that ought to be there, let me know
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:08): lol
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:09): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: can I have your ear?
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:10): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: i am wondering if Opera implements, or plans to implement safari's "device-pixel-ratio" css media query. would you know?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:11): that's the ration between CSS and normal pixels?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:12): ratio*
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:13): yes
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:13): that could be useful
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:13): e.g. 1 CSS pixel to 3 device pixels would be 3.0
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:14): euh
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:15): 1 to 4 makes 2 sounds more logical
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:15): anyway, if it's defined somewhere it might make sense to look into it
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:15): it's one-dimentional
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:15): well it's explained here http://webkit.org/blog/55/high-dpi-web-sites/
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:15): one-dimentional?
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:15): though hyatt hasn't written up a formal defn i think
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:16): I learned that blog posts (with cat pictures on top) are not specs
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:16): some years ago
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:16): oh so you mean 1 to 9 makes 3?
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:16): no
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:16): it doesn't make sense to scale a pixel in just one direction
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:17): unless I'm missing something
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:17): the ratio is applied in both directions
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:17): yeah, so 1 to 9 makes 3
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:17): think of it as the sqrt of the difference in number of pixels
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:18): or better yet, think of it as the zoom factor
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:19): 200% zoom would produce a factor of 2.0  (i.e. 2.0 squared more pixels per image)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:19): I think I understand it correctly as I explained above
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:20): okay :)
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:24): so I'm guessing opera doesn't support it yet. who would be the person to speak to about getting it implemented?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:27): you could file a bug report
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:27): where to?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:29): http://bugs.opera.com/
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:30): should I request an account or use the plebeian option?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (14:30): I suppose the latter
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (14:30): ok
